   28 yo man with h/o recent admission with complicated hospital course
   readmitted for seizures, c/b SMV thrombus, UTI, and increasing
   WBC/lipase, now transferred to MICU s/p PEA arrest.
   PEA arrest:  Most likely related to mucous plugging and associated
   hypoxia.  [**Month (only) 8**] also have been exacerbated by hypoglycemia.  Post-arrest
   he had copious secretions.  Bronchoscopy with edematous airways,
   cultures pending.  CXR post-arrest also concerning for new infiltrate
   in RLL.
   - monitor on telemetry and continuous oxygen monitoring
   - Frequent suctioning prn
   - linezolid, aztrenoman and ciprofloxacin day [**2-11**] for VAP
   - Cont bactrim for UTI and po vanc for empiric C. diff coverage for now
   - f/u cultures
   - F/u Neuro and ID recs
   - wlll discontinue standing D51/2 NS and closely monitor finger sticks
   - plan for EEG today to assess for seizure activity, for now will
   continue standing ativan and keppra
   Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures:  Neurologic exam worsening since arrest.
   Initially concerned for herniation but CT head and MRI showed no
   significant progression since prior studies.  Given right gaze
   preference and hyperreflexia on the right there is continued concern
   for seizures.  He is receiving standing ativan and keppra with plans
   for EEG today.
   - continue keppra [**2122**] mg [**Hospital1 **] change to IV
   - standing ativan 2 mg Q4H change to IV
   - maintain SBP < 180
   - EEG today
   - appreciate neurologic consult
   Hypertension: Patient was significantly hypertensive in the setting of
   receiving epinephrine in the code setting.  Now blooid pressures in the
   low 100s systolic.
   - Standing ativan for possible seizure
   - Hydral prn for SBP >180
   Hypoglycemia:  During PEA arrest patinet was noted to have a blood
   glucose in the 20s in the setting of holding tube feeds and receiving
   regular dose standing lantus.  Standing lantus now discontinued and on
   a cautious sliding scale.
   - Hold glargine for now with liberal ISS
   - will discontinue D51/2 NS
   - QID finger sticks
   - treat infection
   - trend lactate
   Hypercalcemia: Unclear etiology, but most likely secondary to bone
   turnover.  Labs notable for elevated serum calcium and low PTH.  Seen
   by endocrine consult service who recommended starting calcitonin.
   - will transition to normal saline today @ 150 cc/hr
   - [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - continue calcitonin
   - holding lasix for fluctuating blood pressure
   - if no improvement in calcium will consider pamidronate
   - SPEP pending
   Low grade fever/leukocytosis: Unclear etiology.  Leukocytosis with
   significant improvement over past 24 hours. Patient with
 positive
   blood cultures from code with gram positive cocci in clusters,
   speciation pending.  Also has exam concerning for new pneumonia.
   Pancreatitis has been of concern but his imaging has shown stable
   pseudocyts.  Although patient is c. diff negative x 3, he continues on
   empiric treatment pending B-toxin assay.  Also on treatmnet for UTI.
   - linezolid, aztreonam, cipro day [**2-11**] for VAP
   - follow blood cultures
   - bactrim for UTI started day [**4-10**]
   - continue empiric treatment fo clostridium difficile pending B-toxin
   assay
   - plans for pancreatic fluid collection drainage on hold for now
   - will trend amylase and lipase
   - follow ID recs
   - d/c femoral line today
   - consider repeat CT scan for reassessment
   Diarrhea/Bowel thickening: CT showed stable bowel thickening; C diff
   was negative multiple times but recommendation per ID to treat
   empirically for C. diff
   - monitor and keep hydrated
   - C. diff stool cytotoxicity assay pending
   - f/u ID, GI recs
   Pancreatitis:  Patient with severe pancreatitis earlier in course of
   critical illness with pseudocyst formation.  On admission patient with
   mild elevation of his transaminases.
   - trending pancreatic enzymes
   - currently receiving feeds via [**Last Name (LF) 1939**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] need to consider
   repositioning
   UTI: Bactrim sensitive Sternotrophomonas
   - continue bactrim for now although likely sensitive to aztreonam as
   well day [**4-10**]
   - f/u ID recs
   SMV thrombus: Thrombus may be related to pancreatitis and inflamation
   in area. LENIs negative.  Heparin gtt held yesterday given concern for
   worsening neurologic exam.
   - restart heparin gtt
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, d/c tube feeds for high
   residuals
   Glycemic Control: Regular insulin sliding scale

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old man with a complicated hospital course, readmitted for seizures, c/o SMV thrombus, UTI, and increasing WBC/lipase levels. He was transferred to the MICU after experiencing a PEA arrest, most likely related to mucous plugging and associated hypoxia. Post-arrest, he had copious secretions, and bronchoscopy showed edematous airways with cultures pending. His CXR also showed a new infiltrate in the right lower lobe, which could indicate pneumonia.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Electrolyte & Fluid Disorder, Other: The patient has an electrolyte imbalance, including hypercalcemia, which is likely secondary to bone turnover. He is being treated with calcitonin and will have his electrolytes monitored.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis with a significant improvement over the past 24 hours. He has positive blood cultures from the code with gram-positive cocci in clusters, speciation pending. He also has an exam concerning for new pneumonia.
3. Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures: The patient's neurological exam is worsening since the arrest. He is receiving standing ativan and keppra with plans for an EEG today.
4. Hypertension: The patient was significantly hypertensive during the code setting but now has low systolic blood pressure. He will be monitored on telemetry and given hydralazine as

His chest X-ray (CXR) showed a new infiltrate in the right lower lobe (RLL), which may indicate pneumonia.

The patient is currently being treated for various medical conditions, including anoxic brain injury, seizures, hypertension, hypotension, hypercalcemia, fever of unknown origin, respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and altered mental status. He is also being monitored for possible complications such as DIC, DVT, pancreatitis, UTI, and C. difficile infection.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of white blood cells (WBC), C-reactive protein (CRP), and serum calcium. His blood cultures are positive for gram-positive cocci in clusters. Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest on the floor. The patient's hospital course has been complicated by several factors, including seizures, a small bowel thrombus, urinary tract infection (UTI), and increasing white blood cell (WBC) count and lipase levels. The patient was transferred to the MICU for further management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Anoxic Brain Damage: The patient's neurologic exam has shown worsening since the arrest, indicating ongoing concern for anoxic brain damage.
2. Hypertension: The patient was significantly hypertensive during the code setting but is now experiencing low blood pressure in the low 100s systolic.
3. Hypoglycemia: The patient experienced hypoglycemia during the PEA arrest and is now on a cautious sliding scale for blood glucose management.
4. Hypercalcemia: The patient has elevated serum calcium levels, most likely secondary to bone turnover. Calcitonin has been started as recommended by the endocrine consult service.
5. Low-grade fever/leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis with significant improvement over the past 24 hours. Blood cultures from the code showed gram-positive cocci in clusters, and speciation is pending. There is also concern for new pneumonia.
6. UTI: The patient has a urinary tract infection, and bactrim has been started.

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission for seizures, complicated hospital course, and readmission for seizures, c/b SMV thrombus, UTI, and increasing WBC/lipase. He was transferred to the MICU after experiencing a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. The patient has been diagnosed with various medical complications, including electrolyte and fluid disorder, leukocytosis, fever of unknown origin, anoxic brain damage, respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, altered mental status, seizure, malignant hypertension, and hypoglycemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: The patient has imbalances in sodium, potassium, chloride, calcium, and magnesium levels. This can lead to symptoms such as muscle weakness, irregular heartbeat, confusion, and kidney problems.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient has an elevated white blood cell count, indicating a possible infection. Infections can lead to symptoms like fever, fatigue, and increased susceptibility to further infections.
3. Fever of Unknown Origin: The patient has a persistent low-grade fever with an unknown cause. Fever can be a sign of infection or other underlying conditions.
4. Anoxic Brain Damage: The patient may have sustained brain damage due to lack of oxygen supply. Symptoms can include cognitive impairment, memory loss, and difficulty with motor functions.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory system is failing,

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 71-year-old male who was admitted to the MICU after experiencing a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest on the floor. The patient required neosynephrine but was quickly weaned off. Neurology recommended standing ativan, MRI brain, CT head, and EEG. The preliminary read of the MRI brain is unchanged, and the CT head is also unchanged. Standing insulin has been discontinued, and the patient is now on a low-dose sliding scale. Bronchoscopy with edematous airways and mucous in the right lower lobe was performed. Clonopin has been discontinued, and heparin gtt has been discontinued pending the final read of the MRI. The patient started on linezolid, aztreonam, and ciprofloxacin for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). An ultrasound of the left lower extremity was negative for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Blood culture results show growth of gram-positive cocci in clusters. The patient's rate has been increased on the ventilator secondary to discomfort and diaphoresis.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient is currently being treated for multiple medical complications including electrolyte and fluid disorder, leukocytosis, fever of unknown origin, anoxic brain damage, respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, altered mental status, seizure, hypertension, hypoglycemia, hypotension, and DVT

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of hepatitis and pancreatitis, presenting with pseudocyst formation. He is currently experiencing hypoxic encephalopathy and seizures. The patient has been hospitalized for a prolonged period and has had a readmission for recalcitrant seizures. He experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest 36 hours ago on the medical floor. The patient's recent events include sputum culture, stool culture, bronchoscopy, ultrasound, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Medical Complications:
1. HCAP (Hospital-acquired pneumonia) - The patient has been prescribed linezolid, aztreonam, and ciprofloxacin for 8 days due to a significant reduction in white blood cell count (WBC).
2. UTI (Urinary tract infection) - Stenotrophomonas bacteria was identified, and the patient has been given bactrim for a complicated UTI.
3. Bacteremia - Gram-positive cocci (GPC) infection is suspected, and the patient will need at least 14 days of antibiotic therapy depending on the source of infection.
4. C. difficile infection - The patient has been diagnosed based on CT findings and will receive oral vancomycin.
5. Mental status - The patient's mental status has been poor post-anoxic, but there is slight improvement observed with the patient squeezing hands. EEG results are pending, and neurology continues to follow up

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of hepatitis and pancreatitis, presenting with pseudocyst formation, hypoxic encephalopathy, and seizures. He has been readmitted to the ICU for recalcitrant seizures following a previous prolonged hospitalization. The patient experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest 36 hours ago on the medical floor. 

Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Encephalopathy: The patient has been experiencing poor mental status and seizures, which could be attributed to hypoxic injury. 
2. Seizures: The patient has recurrent seizures, and the differential diagnosis includes further hypoxic injury, ongoing delirium, or other underlying neurological conditions.
3. Sepsis: The patient's condition suggests possible sepsis due to the presence of multiple infections, including hospital-acquired pneumonia (HCAP), urinary tract infection (UTI), and bacteremia caused by Gram-positive cocci (GPC).
4. Hypercalcemia: The patient has elevated calcium levels, which may be due to bone turnover. This condition requires further evaluation and management.
5. Pancreatitis and Pseudocyst: The patient has a history of pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation. Further consideration for definitive therapy is needed when the patient is more stable.
6. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has negative lower extremity Doppler ultrasound results, ruling out DVT.
7. Catheter

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old man with a complicated hospital course, including seizures, a superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombus, urinary tract infection (UTI), and increasing white blood cell (WBC) count and lipase levels. He was readmitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU) after experiencing a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, which was likely due to mucous plugging and associated hypoxia from pneumonia. The patient's mental status has worsened due to hypoglycemia. He has bronchoscopic findings of gram-negative rods (GNR) and gram-positive cocci (GPC) in clusters, likely contaminants from the femoral line. The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and UTI. His neurological exam is concerning for seizures, and he is on anticonvulsant therapy. Other issues include hypertension, hypercalcemia, low-grade fever, leukocytosis, and gastrointestinal (GI) residuals. The patient's condition remains unstable with ongoing medical complications. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has a history of GNR infection, which is commonly associated with VAP. Continuous monitoring and appropriate antibiotic therapy are essential to prevent further complications.
2. Seizures: The patient's neurological exam suggests ongoing seizure activity, which can be a result of anoxic brain injury. Close monitoring

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission and a complicated hospital course. He was readmitted for seizures, clogged mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombus, urinary tract infection (UTI), and increasing white blood cell (WBC) and lipase levels. The patient experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and was resuscitated. He is now in the medical intensive care unit (MICU) with multiple medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Electrolyte & Fluid Disorder: The patient has imbalances in his electrolytes, including hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, and hypoglycemia. Close monitoring and appropriate treatment are necessary.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is elevated, indicating an infection or inflammation. Blood cultures have been taken, and antibiotics have been started.
3. Anoxic Brain Damage (Anoxic Encephalopathy, Hypoxic Ischemic): The patient had a PEA arrest, which resulted in oxygen deprivation to the brain. Neurological exams show worsening since the arrest, but imaging studies show no significant progression. Seizure activity is still a concern.
4. Pancreatitis, Acute (Necrotizing Pancreatitis): The patient has had elevated lipase levels and evidence of pancreatic inflammation. Although pseudocysts have formed, drainage is currently on hold.
5. Respiratory Failure, Acute

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 71-inch tall individual with a weight of 250cc. They have been admitted to the ICU and have a history of altered mental status, seizure, anoxic brain damage, acute respiratory failure, necrotizing pancreatitis, sepsis without organ dysfunction, hypotension, and hypercalcemia. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C (99.9°F), heart rate of 120 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 130/63 mmHg to 107/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is on continuous monitoring, multi-lumen central line, and has had blood cultures drawn from both the right arm and femoral line.

Medical Complications that can arise:
1. Sepsis: Given the presence of multiple organisms in the blood cultures, there is a risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction.
2. Infection: The patient's immune system may be compromised due to underlying conditions, increasing the risk of infections.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on ventilatory support, indicating acute respiratory failure. There is a risk of further deterioration in respiratory function.
4. Pancreatitis: Necrotizing pancreatitis has been diagnosed, which can lead to complications such as pancreatic necrosis, abscess formation, or systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).
5. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and anoxic brain damage increase the risk of neurological complications, including potential long-term deficits.
6. Hypercalcemia: The patient's corrected calcium level is elevated, which may require further management to prevent complications such as renal dysfunction or cardiac arrhythmias.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition are sepsis, infection, respiratory failure, pancreatitis, neurological complications, and hypercalcemia.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a complicated hospital course readmitted for seizures, c. diff colitis, UTI, and increasing WBC/lipase levels. He was transferred to the MICU after experiencing a PEA arrest, likely due to mucous plugging and associated hypoxia, exacerbated by hypoglycemia. Post-arrest, he had copious secretions, and bronchoscopy with edematous airways, cultures pending. His CXR also showed a new infiltrate in the right lower lobe.

The patient is currently on multiple medications, including antibiotics for VAP and UTI, anticonvulsants for possible seizures, and medications for various other conditions such as hypertension, hypoglycemia, hypercalcemia, and low-grade fever/leukocytosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures: The patient's neurological exam has been worsening since the arrest, and there is continued concern for seizures. He is receiving standing ativan and keppra with plans for an EEG today.
2. Hypertension: The patient was significantly hypertensive during the code setting and is now experiencing low blood pressures in the low 100s systolic.
3. Hypoglycemia: During the PEA arrest, the patient had a blood glucose in the 20s, and standing lantus has been discontinued. A cautious sliding scale is being used.
4. Hypercalcemia: The patient has elevated serum calcium and low PTH, likely secondary to bone turnover. He is being treated with calcitonin and will have further evaluation.
5. Low-grade fever/leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis with significant improvement over the past 24 hours. He has positive blood cultures from the code with gram-positive cocci in clusters, speciation pending. He also has an exam concerning for new pneumonia.
6. Pancreatitis: The patient has severe pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation. His pancreatic enzymes are being trended, and he is receiving feeds via a feeding tube.
7. UTI: The patient has a sensitive Sternotrophomonas infection, for which he is being treated with bactrim.
8. SMV thrombus: The thrombus may be related to pancreatitis and inflammation in the area. Heparin gtt was held initially due to concern for worsening neurologic exam but will be continued.
9. VAP: The patient is at risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia, and measures such as HOB elevation and mouth care are being implemented.

Please note that this summary and potential medical complications are based on the provided progress note, and further evaluation and assessment may be required for a comprehensive understanding of the patient's condition.

The patient had a previous admission for a mucous plug-related pulmonary embolism, which led to a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest. He was resuscitated and transferred to the MICU.

The patient's current condition includes anoxic brain injury/seizures, hypoglycemia, hypercalcemia, low-grade fever/leukocytosis, rash, gastrointestinal residuals, diarrhea/bowel thickening, hypertension, pancreatitis, urinary tract infection (UTI), SMV thrombus, and non-gap metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and has developed a GNR infection in the bronchoalveolar lavage culture. Antibiotics have been started for VAP.
2. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI): There is evidence of GPC infection from the femoral line, which may be a contaminant. The femoral line has been removed.
3. Drug-induced rash: The patient has developed a rash, which may be related to medication.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient has had an episode of severe pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation. Pancreatic enzymes are now

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male admitted to the ICU for sepsis without organ dysfunction, altered mental status, seizure, hypotension, respiratory failure, anoxic brain damage, leukocytosis, electrolyte & fluid disorder, and acute pancreatitis. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 120 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 130/63 to 132/91 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99%, and sinus tachycardia as the heart rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, but normal creatinine levels. Glucose levels have been fluctuating between 74 and 180 mg/dL. Other lab values indicate abnormalities in electrolytes, liver enzymes, and pancreatic enzymes.

The patient has been on multiple medications, including antibiotics (vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, linezolid, aztreonam), antiepileptic drugs (keppra, ativan), and other ICU medications (heparin sodium, famotidine, lorazepam).

The patient's recent events include removal of a multi-lumen catheter, blood cultures drawn from both the right arm PICC and left femoral line, tip of the femoral line sent for culture, correction of hypercalcemia with calcitonin, and changes in IV medications due

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 71-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status. The patient experienced a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and was resuscitated. Initial assessment revealed possible mucus plugging and acute hypoxia as the cause of the arrest. However, given the rapid improvement and presence of secretions on bronchoscopies, pneumonia (PE) seems less likely, and the patient is now on anticoagulation for a superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombus.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues. He is being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HCAP) with linezolid, aztreonam, and ciprofloxacin for 8 days. White blood cell count has dramatically reduced, and gram-negative rods are awaiting speciation. The patient also has a complicated urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Stenotrophomonas, for which he will receive 7 days of bactrim. If urine analysis is negative, bactrim may be discontinued. Additionally, the patient has bacteremia with gram-positive cocci (GPC), awaiting source identification and minimum 14-day treatment depending on the source. Surveillance cultures will be checked to guide further antibiotic therapy.

The patient is also being treated for Clostridium difficile infection (C.diff) based on CT findings. Oral vancomycin was administered, and it was discontinued due to a negative assay.

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission for pancreatitis, pseudocyst, ARDS, respiratory failure, and a previous cardiac arrest on 6-11, resulting in hypoxic encephalopathy and seizures. He was readmitted for seizures on 7-9 due to a superior mesenteric vein thrombus, urinary tract infection, and increasing white blood cell count and lipase levels. He then experienced another PEA arrest on 7-19 and was transferred to the MICU.

The patient's current vital signs show a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 124 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 125/65 to 132/91 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 of 50%. His general appearance is alert and interactive. He has multiple skin tears on his medial upper left extremity, bilateral lower extremities, and erythematous blanching rash on his bilateral upper extremities. He also has 3+ lower extremity edema and diffuse anasarca.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, and troponin-T levels. Other lab values indicate hypercalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and hyponatremia. The patient is currently on multiple medications including antibiotics, anticoag

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male with a complicated hospital course. The patient has been admitted multiple times for various conditions, including pancreatitis with pseudocyst, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), respiratory failure, PEA arrest, hypoxic encephalopathy, and seizures.

The current assessment indicates several medical complications that need to be managed:

1. Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HCAP): The patient has been diagnosed with HCAP and is currently being treated with linezolid, aztreonam, and ciprofloxacin. Pseudomonas aeruginosa has been identified in the bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL), and both aztreonam and ciprofloxacin will be continued.

2. Bacteremia: The patient has bacteremia caused by Gram-positive cocci. A minimum of 14 days of antibiotic therapy is recommended, depending on the source of the infection. Linezolid will be continued for an additional 48 hours after obtaining surveillance cultures.

3. Rash: The patient has developed a rash, which is suspected to be a drug eruption. The anticonvulsant medication, keppra, was recently changed, and bactrim has been stopped. No evidence of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is present.

4. Urinary tract infection (UTI): Stenotrophomonas maltophilia has grown from the second urine culture. Further therapy will be discussed

The patient also had exacerbated mental status due to hypoglycemia. Bronchoscopy with edematous airways; BAL culture growing GNR. GPC in 2-7 bottles from fem line likely contaminant; Femoral line removed.

The patient is currently on multiple medications, including antibiotics (aztreonam, ciprofloxacin, linezolid), antiepileptic drugs (lorazepam, levetiracetam), and other ICU medications (heparin, famotidine, lorazepam).

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C (99.9°F), heart rate of 111 bpm, blood pressure of 130/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on CPAP/PSV mode with FiO2 of 50%. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 28-year-old woman with a history of heavy alcohol abuse and complications related to portal hypertension. She was readmitted to the hospital for a seizure and was found to have a superior mesenteric vein thrombus and urinary tract infection. She was transferred to the ICU on July 19th for a cardiac arrest. The patient's current conditions include hypoxic encephalopathy due to the cardiac arrest, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, bacteremia with GPCs, a drug rash, urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, altered mental status, hypercalcemia, and a possible pseudocyst in the pancreas.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. s/p PEA arrest - The patient experienced a sudden cardiac arrest, which could have led to mucus plugging and acute hypoxia. Although she has shown rapid improvement, it is essential to continue monitoring her condition.
2. VAP - The patient has developed ventilator-associated pneumonia caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. She is currently receiving linezolid, aztreonam, and ciprofloxacin. It is important to continue these antibiotics for an extended period to treat the infection effectively.
3. Bacteremia - The patient has bacteremia with GPCs, and the specific bacteria are still awaiting identification. The plan is to continue linez

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 28-year-old female with a history of heavy alcohol abuse, complications of portal hypertension, and previous hypoxic encephalopathy due to a cardiac arrest. She was readmitted from rehabilitation for seizures and found to have a superior mesenteric vein thrombus and urinary tract infection. She was transferred to the ICU on July 19th for a second cardiac arrest.

The patient's current condition includes:
1. Suspected mucus plugging and acute hypoxia during the cardiac arrest, but rapid improvement and presence of secretions on bronchoscopy suggest less likely pulmonary embolism (now on anticoagulation for SMV thrombus). Monitoring continues.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, for which she is receiving linezolid, aztreonam, and ciprofloxacin for 8 days.
3. Bacteremia with Gram-positive cocci (GPC), awaiting speciation. Plan to continue linezolid for 48 hours after obtaining surveillance culture results.
4. Rash concerning for drug eruption, especially with recent changes in anticonvulsant medication. Bactrim has been stopped after 5 days.
5. Urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, which is now growing from a second urine culture. Further therapy discussion with Infectious Disease specialist is needed.
6. Mild improvement in mental

Summary:
The patient is a 71-inch, 98.8 kg male with a medical history of s/p PEA arrest and anoxic brain injury, s/p trach and peg. The patient's chief complaint is anoxic brain injury.

The 24-hour events include:
- Changing aztreonam to tobramycin per ID recommendations
- Continuing linezolid and obtaining blood cultures with GPCs
- Weaning PS from PEEP 12 to 8
- Changing PTT goal for hep gtt to 50-70
- Changing ativan dosing from q4hr to q6hrs per neuro recommendations
- Increasing calcitonin to 320 mg and adding pamidronate x1 to potentially wean off calcitonin in the next 4 days
- Holding TFs due to high residuals and adding reglan
- Tachy up from 110s to 120s and giving a 500 cc bolus
- Having increased secretions
- Adjusting bicarb levels

The patient has allergies to meropenem.

The last doses of antibiotics were as follows:

   Assessment and Plan
   28 yo man with h/o recent admission with complicated hospital course
   readmitted for seizures, c/b SMV thrombus, UTI, and increasing
   WBC/lipase, now transferred to MICU s/p PEA arrest.
   PEA arrest: Most likely related to mucous plugging and associated
   hypoxia from pneumonia given copious secretions and RLL infiltrate on
   post-arrest CXR. [**Month (only) 8**] have been exacerbated by worsened mental status
   from hypoglycemia. Bronchoscopy with edematous airways; BAL cx growing
   GNR. GPC in [**2-7**] bottles from fem line likely contaminant; Femoral line
   removed.
   - monitor on telemetry and continuous oxygen monitoring
   - frequent suctioning prn
   - switching aztreonam to tobramycin; cont cipro for [**Last Name (LF) 3005**], [**First Name3 (LF) 124**] complete
   8 d course.  D1 = [**7-23**].
   - cont linezolid until GPCs speciated
   - stopped bactrim for UTI
   - off po vanc as no evidence for C diff although cytotoxicity assay
   still pending
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u ID recs
   - closely monitor finger sticks
   - cont standing ativan and keppra while EEG pending, although widened
   interval btw ativan to q6hrs from q4hrs
   Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures:  Neurologic exam worsening since arrest.
   Initially concerned for herniation but CT head and MRI showed no
   significant progression since prior studies.  Given right gaze
   preference and hyperreflexia on the right there is continued concern
   for seizures.  He is receiving standing ativan and keppra pending EEG
   results.
   - no evidence of seizures yet
   - cont keppra [**2122**] mg [**Hospital1 **] IV
   - change ativan to q 6hrs, consider change to clonazepam in future per
   neuro recs
   - maintain SBP < 180
   - f/u EEG
   - f/u neuro recs
   Hypoglycemia:  During PEA arrest, patient was noted to have a blood
   glucose in the 20s in the setting of holding tube feeds and receiving
   regular dose standing lantus.  Standing lantus now discontinued and on
   a cautious sliding scale.
   - Hold glargine for now with liberal ISS
   - QID finger sticks
   - treat infection
   Hypercalcemia: Unclear etiology, but most likely secondary to bone
   turnover from being immobile and poor kidney excretion.  Labs notable
   for elevated serum calcium and low PTH.  Started on calcitonin per Endo
   recs.
   - appreciate Endo recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - increased dose of calcitonin and started pamidronate today, expect
   pamidronate to take about 4 days to work and can try to taper off the
   calcitonin during this time frame
   - f/u SPEP
   Low grade fever/leukocytosis: Leukocytosis stable. Likely [**2-5**] [**Month/Day (2) 3005**] with
   BAL cx growing GNR.  Also with 2 of 4 bcx growing GPC, which may
   represent contamination. Continuing tx for Sternotrophomonas UTI.  C.
   diff tx discontinued as assay neg x 3; B-toxin assay pending.
   Pancreatitis has been of concern but his imaging has shown pseudocysts
   but not felt to be infected; LFTs and pancreatic enzymes now improving.
   - 8-day course tobra and cipro for [**Month/Day (2) 3005**]
   - cont linezolid pending speciation of blood cx
   - stopped bactrim
   - off vanc as C. diff neg x 3; f/u cytotoxicity assay
   - no plan for pancreatic fluid collection drainage at this time
   - trend amylase and lipase
   - follow ID recs
   - consider repeat CT scan for reassessment
   Rash: concerning for drug rash
   - d/c bactrim
   GI Residuals: Concern for ileus although pt having BM
   - restart tubefeeds and check residual
   - will start reglan today if there is no interaction with seizure meds
   Diarrhea/Bowel thickening: CT showed stable bowel thickening; C diff
   was negative multiple times so stopped PO vanc per ID
   - monitor and keep hydrated
   - C. diff stool cytotoxicity assay pending
   - f/u ID, GI recs
   Hypertension: Patient was significantly hypertensive in the setting of
   receiving epinephrine in the code setting as well as pronounced clonus,
   ?seizure activity. Now normotensive.
   - Cont keppra with standing ativan for now
   - Hydral prn for SBP >180
   Pancreatitis:  Patient with severe pancreatitis earlier in course of
   critical illness with pseudocyst formation.  On admission patient with
   mild elevation of his transaminases. LFTs and pancreatitic enzymes now
   improving.
   - trending pancreatic enzymes
   - TFs being held in setting of  high residuals
   UTI: Bactrim sensitive Sternotrophomonas
   - continue bactrim for now although likely sensitive to the tobra that
   is being started as well
   SMV thrombus: Thrombus may be related to pancreatitis and inflamation
   in area. LENIs negative.  Heparin gtt held initially given concern for
   worsening neurologic exam but restarted
   - continue heparin gtt

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for complicated hospital course, readmission for seizures, c/b SMV thrombus, UTI, and increasing WBC/lipase, now transferred to MICU s/p PEA arrest. The patient experienced a PEA arrest likely related to mucous plugging and associated hypoxia from pneumonia, exacerbated by worsened mental status from hypoglycemia.    Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures:  Neurologic exam worsening since arrest.
   Initially concerned for herniation but CT head and MRI showed no
   significant progression since prior studies.  Given right gaze
   preference and hyperreflexia on the right there is continued concern
   for seizures.  He is receiving standing ativan and keppra pending EEG
   results.
   - no evidence of seizures yet

   - change ativan to q 6hrs, consider change to clonazepam in future per

   - f/u neuro recs
   Hypoglycemia:  During PEA arrest, patient was noted to have a blood

   - Hold glargine for now with liberal ISS

   - treat infection

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission for severe pancreatitis and complications including a SMV thrombus, UTI, and increasing WBC and lipase levels. He was readmitted for seizures, and transferred to the MICU after experiencing a PEA arrest. The arrest was likely related to mucous plugging and associated hypoxia from pneumonia, exacerbated by worsened mental status from hypoglycemia. Bronchoscopy with edematous airways; BAL cx growing GNR. The patient's femoral line was also removed.

The patient is currently on multiple medications including fosphenytoin for ongoing seizure activity, fentanyl for pain control, tube feeds placed to suction, and various antibiotics for infections such as UTI and pneumonia. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he continues to have a low-grade fever and leukocytosis, likely due to the ongoing infection. The patient's electrolytes are also abnormal, with hypercalcemia and low PTH, which may be secondary to bone turnover from being immobile and poor kidney excretion. He has been started on calcitonin and pamidronate to manage the hypercalcemia.

The patient's neurological status is a concern, with worsening neurologic exam since the arrest. There is suspicion of anoxic brain injury and seizures, but imaging has shown no significant progression. He is receiving standing ativan and keppra for seizure prophylaxis, and his blood

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male with pancreatitis, acute respiratory failure, anoxic brain damage, and seizures. He has been hospitalized for a prolonged period and has developed complications such as necrotizing pancreatitis, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), sepsis without organ dysfunction, altered mental status (not delirium), and seizure without status epilepticus.

The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation through a tracheostomy tube and is tolerating pressure support ventilation. He is being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with appropriate antibiotics. The patient's seizures have been controlled with fosphenytoin, and he is also on Keppra and Ativan for seizure management.

The patient has hypercalcemia, which is being treated with calcitonin and pamidronate. He has fevers, which are attributed to VAP and a stenotrophomonas UTI, and linezolid has been discontinued per Infectious Disease consultation. There is also a thrombus in the superior mesenteric vein (SMV), for which he is receiving heparin.

The patient has metabolic acidosis, and non-gap metabolic acidosis is being treated with normal saline (NS) infusion cessation. The patient's nutrition is a concern, and enteral feeds will be restarted. If the patient continues to have high residuals, a post-pyloric placement may be beneficial.

In terms of ICU care,

The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, acute respiratory failure, anoxic brain damage, and seizures. He has been hospitalized for a prolonged period and has developed multiple complications, including necrotizing pancreatitis, SMV thrombosis, sepsis without organ dysfunction, altered mental status, and seizure activity. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and is tolerating pressure support ventilation. He is also experiencing hypercalcemia, leukocytosis, and has had recent infections such as ventilator-associated pneumonia and urinary tract infection. The patient's abdominal imaging shows pseudocysts that have not changed appreciably, and he is on heparin for the SMV thrombus. The patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and management of his various medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and tolerating pressure support ventilation. It is important to continue monitoring his respiratory status and adjusting ventilator settings as needed to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation.

2. Anoxic Brain Injury: The patient has suffered anoxic brain damage due to prolonged periods of inadequate oxygen supply to the brain. Recovery from anoxic brain injury can be unpredictable, and it is important to continue neurological monitoring and provide appropriate supportive care.

3. Hypercalcemia: The patient has elevated calcium levels which need to be managed with medications such as pamidronate and calcitonin. Close

   readmitted for seizures, c/b SMV thrombus, UTI, and increasing
   WBC/lipase, was transferred to MICU s/p PEA arrest.
   .
   Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures:  Neurologic exam worsening, now
   persistent since arrest.  Initially concerned for herniation but CT
   head and MRI showed no significant progression since prior studies.
   Given right gaze preference and hyperreflexia on the right there is
   continued concern for seizures.  He is receiving standing ativan and
   keppra as EEG showing persisent seizure activity.
   - yesterday
s EEG showing evidence of likely status.
   - cont keppra [**2122**] mg [**Hospital1 **] IV
   - change ativan to q 6hrs, loaded with fosphenytoin yesterday, will
   continue to load today with 500mg then 200mg this PM.  Then 100mg [**Hospital1 **].
   - maintain SBP < 180
   - f/u EEG
   - f/u neuro recs
   .
   Eosinophilia.  Continues to trend up.
   .
   PEA arrest: Most likely related to mucous plugging and associated
   hypoxia from pneumonia given copious secretions and RLL infiltrate on
   post-arrest CXR. [**Month (only) 8**] have been exacerbated by worsened mental status
   from hypoglycemia. Bronchoscopy with edematous airways; BAL cx growing
   GNR. GPC in [**2-7**] bottles from fem line likely contaminant; Femoral line
   removed.
   - monitor on telemetry and continuous oxygen monitoring
   - frequent suctioning prn
   - switched aztreonam to tobramycin; cont cipro for [**Last Name (LF) 3005**], [**First Name3 (LF) 124**] complete 8
   d course.  D1 = [**7-23**].
   - cont linezolid until GPCs speciated, per ID will DC today.
   - stopped bactrim for UTI
   - off po vanc as no evidence for C diff although cytotoxicity assay
   still pending
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u ID recs
   - closely monitor finger sticks
   - cont standing ativan and keppra, loaded on fosphenytoin yesterday.
   Hypoglycemia:  During PEA arrest, patient was noted to have a blood
   glucose in the 20s in the setting of holding tube feeds and receiving
   regular dose standing lantus.  Standing lantus now discontinued and on
   a cautious sliding scale.
   - Hold glargine for now with liberal ISS
   - QID finger sticks
   - treat infection
   Hypercalcemia: Unclear etiology, but most likely secondary to bone
   turnover from being immobile and poor kidney excretion.  Labs notable
   for elevated serum calcium and low PTH.  Started on calcitonin per Endo
   recs.
   - appreciate Endo recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - increased dose of calcitonin and started pamidronate yesterday.,
   expect pamidronate to take about 4 days to work and can try to taper
   off the calcitonin during this time frame
   - f/u SPEP
   Low grade fever/leukocytosis: Leukocytosis stable. Likely [**2-5**] [**Month/Day (2) 3005**] with
   BAL cx growing GNR.  Also with 2 of 4 bcx growing GPC, which may
   represent contamination. Continuing tx for Sternotrophomonas UTI.  C.
   diff tx discontinued as assay neg x 3; B-toxin assay pending.
   Pancreatitis has been of concern but his imaging has shown pseudocysts
   but not felt to be infected; LFTs and pancreatic enzymes now improving.
   - 8-day course tobra and cipro for [**Month/Day (2) 3005**]
   - off vanc as C. diff neg x 3; f/u cytotoxicity assay
   -DC bactrim and linezolid.
   - no plan for pancreatic fluid collection drainage at this time
   - trend amylase and lipase
   - follow ID recs
   - consider repeat CT scan for reassessment
   Rash: concerning for drug rash
   - d/c bactrim
   GI Residuals: Concern for ileus although pt having BM
   - restart tubefeeds and check residual
   - reglan started.
   Diarrhea/Bowel thickening: CT showed stable bowel thickening; C diff
   was negative multiple times so stopped PO vanc per ID
   - monitor and keep hydrated
   - C. diff stool cytotoxicity assay pending
   - f/u ID, GI recs
   Hypertension: Patient was significantly hypertensive in the setting of
   receiving epinephrine in the code setting as well as pronounced clonus,
   ?seizure activity. Now normotensive.
   - Cont keppra with standing ativan for now
   - Hydral prn for SBP >180
   Pancreatitis:  Patient with severe pancreatitis earlier in course of
   critical illness with pseudocyst formation.  On admission patient with
   mild elevation of his transaminases. LFTs and pancreatitic enzymes now
   improving.
   - trending pancreatic enzymes
   - TFs being held in setting of  high residuals
   -underwent repeat CT scan yesterday showing continuation of
   pseudocysts. Gen [**Doctor First Name 91**] reconsulted yesterday. No plans for surgical
   intervention at this time. Will need repeat imaging and f/u in the

   UTI: Bactrim sensitive Sternotrophomonas
   - continue bactrim for now although likely sensitive to the tobra that

   SMV thrombus: Thrombus may be related to pancreatitis and inflamation

   Assessment and Plan
   28 yo man with h/o recent admission with necrotizing pancreatitis c/b
   pseudocysts, s/p PEA arrest x2 with anoxic brain injury and seizure,
   being treated for VAP with tobra/cipro.
   .
   AMS secondary to Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures.  Patient has suffered
   two PEA arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity.  Not
   interactive.  He was previously in has been loaded with phenytoin.  No
   longer receiving continue EEG monitor.  Prognosis regarding mental
   status is poor.
   - continue keppra 1 g [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue phenytoin 100 mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue standing ativan
   - f/u neuro recs
   . .
   Respiratory failure/VAP.  Patient has been on TCM for 24 hours and
   tolerating it well.  Has a vigorous cough.  On tobra/cipro with plan
   for two week course to be completed [**8-3**].
   - continue tobra/cipro (though this may be contributing to
   eosinophilia)
   - continue TCM
   .
   Pancreatitis:  Patient with severe necrotizing pancreatitis earlier in
   course of critical illness with pseudocyst formation.  No plans for
   surgical invention.  Lipase is trending down.  CT scan of the abdomen
   on [**7-25**] shows stable pancreatic pseudocysts.
   - trending pancreatic enzymes
   - tolerating tube feeds
   Eosinophilia.  Continues to trend up in spite of being off bactrim for
   several days.  Most concerning meds are tobra which was recently added,
   linezolid which has already been stopped, cipro which patient has been
   on for 6 days, and dilantin which is new.
   - continue tobra/cipro for now
   - continue dilantin for now
   - trend eos count
   .
   S/p PEA arrest.  This is felt to be secondary to mucous plugging from
   VAP.  Additionally, patient was hypoglycemic on the floor in setting of
   recently starting glargine.
   - monitor on tele
   Diabetes.  Had hypoglycemia during PEA arrest after initation of
   glargine.  Now that patient is finally tolerating tube feeds,
   anticipate patient will have hyperglycemia.
   - follow fingersticks and cover with HISS
   - if long acting insulin is needed will start low given recent
   hypoglycemia
   .
   Hypercalcemia: Unclear etiology, but most likely secondary to bone
   turnover from being immobile and poor kidney excretion.
   - appreciate Endo recs
   - continue calcitonin and s/p pamidronate
   - follow ca and monitor for hypocalcemia
   .
   SMV thrombus.  Therapeutic on heparin drip for SMV thrombus likely
   secondary to severe pancreatitis.
   - continue heparin gtt with goal of 50-70 for PTT
   - initiate bridging with coumadin with plan for 6 month course
   .
   Tachycardia.  No clear etiology of tachycardia.  Patient is not
   withdrawing and is on standing ativan.  Did not respond to fentanyl
   boluses.  [**Month (only) 8**] be dehydrated as patient was NPO with no IVFs for several
   day.
   - bolus with NS to look for HR response
   .
   Metabolic acidosis.  Likely multifactorial secondary to prior NGT
   suctioning, seizures.
   - follow bicarb

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 28-year-old man who was admitted with necrotizing pancreatitis and pseudocysts. He experienced two episodes of pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest, resulting in anoxic brain injury and seizure activity. The patient is currently being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with tobramycin and ciprofloxacin. He is also receiving antianxiety medication, phenytoin for seizures, and pain management.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures: The patient has suffered anoxic brain injury with seizure activity. Prognosis regarding mental status is poor. Continue keppra 1 g, phenytoin 100 mg, and standing ativan. Follow neuro recommendations.
2. Respiratory Failure/VAP: The patient has been on tracheostomy (TCM) for 24 hours and tolerating it well. Continue tobra/cipro for two-week course to be completed on 08/03. Continue TCM.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has severe necrotizing pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation. No plans for surgical intervention. Trending pancreatic enzymes. Tolerating tube feeds. Stable pancreatic pseudocysts on CT scan of the abdomen on 07/25.
4. Eosinophilia: Continue tobra/cipro for now. Continue dilantin for now. Trend eos count.
5. S/p

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a prolonged hospitalization following pancreatitis, pseudocyst, SMV thrombosis, acute respiratory failure, PEA arrest, seizures, and hypercalcemia. The patient's acute respiratory failure has resolved, but he remains on a tracheal collar and is stable. He is also experiencing anoxic brain injury/Altered Mental Status (AMS) due to recent anoxia, continued seizure activity, hypercalcemia, and medications. The patient's hypercalcemia has been treated with pamidronate and calcitonin, and his levels are still high. He has leukocytosis, which is being covered for Pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and Stenotrophomonas urinary tract infection (UTI). The patient is tolerating tube feeds and has a history of pancreatitis with pseudocysts that have not changed appreciably. He also has a SMV thrombus, for which he will require six months of anticoagulation. The patient's current disposition is stable in the ICU, but he may need to be on the floor in the next 24 hours. He is at high risk for requiring ICU-level care for respiratory status due to suctioning needs.

Potential medical complications:
1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient has already experienced this complication but has been resolved.
2. Anoxic brain injury/Altered Mental Status (AMS): The patient is unlikely

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male with a prolonged hospitalization following pancreatitis and associated complications. The key points from the note are as follows:

1. The patient has a history of pseudocyst formation due to pancreatitis.
2. There was an acute respiratory failure episode, which has resolved.
3. The patient experienced two episodes of PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity) arrest.
4. Seizures have been ongoing, and the patient is currently on fosphenytoin, Keppra, and lorazepam.
5. The patient has anoxic brain injury and altered mental status (AMS), with no obvious neurological changes.
6. Hypercalcemia has been treated with pamidronate and calcitonin.
7. The patient has leukocytosis, which is being covered for possible Pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and stenotrophomonas urinary tract infection (UTI).
8. Eosinophilia may be related to new medications or antibiotics.
9. Abdominal imaging shows pseudocysts without evidence of super-infection.
10. The patient has a superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombosis, for which anticoagulation therapy is required.
11. The patient's respiratory status is unstable, making him a candidate for continued ICU care.

   Assessment and Plan
   28 yo man with h/o recent admission with necrotizing pancreatitis c/b
   pseudocysts, s/p PEA arrest x2 with anoxic brain injury and seizure,
   being treated for VAP with tobra/cipro.
   .
   AMS secondary to Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures.  Patient has suffered
   two PEA arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity.  Not
   interactive.  He was previously in has been loaded with phenytoin.  No
   longer receiving continue EEG monitor.  Prognosis regarding mental
   status is poor.
   - continue keppra 1 g [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue phenytoin 100 mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue standing ativan
   - neuro recommends to continue current therapy, may consider switching
   dilantin due to interaction with coumadin
   . .
   Respiratory failure/VAP.  Patient has been on TCM for 24 hours and
   tolerating it well.  Has a vigorous cough.  On tobra/cipro with plan
   for two week course to be completed [**8-3**].  Pt  coughing worsened
   overnight, oxygenating well but appeared uncomfortable especially with
   worsened tachycardia.  Switched to PS and improved.
   - continue tobra/cipro (end date [**8-3**])
   - continue nebs PRN
   - return to TCM today
   - consider trach change as having worsening erythema and mild discharge
   around trach
   .
   Tachycardia.  No clear etiology of tachycardia.  Patient is not
   withdrawing and is on standing ativan.  Did not respond to fentanyl
   boluses or extra ativan doses.  Did not respond it IVF boluses,
   either.  Seemed to worsen with coughing fits.
   - consider new infection if fever spikes
   - consider PE if respiratory sats drop
   .
   Pancreatitis:  Patient with severe necrotizing pancreatitis earlier in
   course of critical illness with pseudocyst formation.  No plans for
   surgical invention.  Lipase is trending down.  CT scan of the abdomen
   on [**7-25**] shows stable pancreatic pseudocysts.
   - trending pancreatic enzymes
   - had high residuals again yesterday, continue tube feeds if possible
   Eosinophilia.  Continues to trend up in spite of being off bactrim for
   several days.  Most concerning meds are tobra which was recently added,
   linezolid which has already been stopped, cipro which patient has been
   on for 6 days, and dilantin which is new.  Is possible to have about 2
   week eosinophilia after stopping Bactrim.
   - continue tobra/cipro for now
   - continue dilantin for now
   - trend eos count
   .
   S/p PEA arrest.  This is felt to be secondary to mucous plugging from
   VAP.  Additionally, patient was hypoglycemic on the floor in setting of
   recently starting glargine.
   - monitor on tele
   Diabetes.  Had hypoglycemia during PEA arrest after initation of
   glargine.  Now that patient is finally tolerating tube feeds,
   anticipate patient will have hyperglycemia.
   - follow fingersticks and cover with HISS
   - if long acting insulin is needed will start low given recent
   hypoglycemia
   .
   Hypercalcemia: Unclear etiology, but most likely secondary to bone
   turnover from being immobile and poor kidney excretion.
   - appreciate Endo recs
   - continue calcitonin and s/p pamidronate
   - follow ca and monitor for hypocalcemia
   .
   SMV thrombus.  Therapeutic on heparin drip for SMV thrombus likely
   secondary to severe pancreatitis.
   - continue heparin gtt with goal of 50-70 for PTT
   - initiate bridging with coumadin with plan for 6 month course
   .
   Metabolic acidosis.  Likely multifactorial secondary to prior NGT
   suctioning, seizures.
   - follow bicarb

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU and potential medical complications that can arise:

Summary:
- The patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis and pseudocysts.
- He suffered two episodes of PEA arrest and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity.
- The patient is being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with Tobramycin and Ciprofloxacin.
- He has AMS secondary to anoxic brain injury/seizures, poor mental status prognosis, and respiratory failure/VAP.
- The patient has tachycardia without a clear etiology, diabetes, hypercalcemia, SMV thrombus, and metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient is at risk for further infections due to his immunocompromised state, tracheostomy site erythema and purulent discharge, and ongoing treatment for VAP.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable with ongoing respiratory failure/VAP despite being on TCM and receiving antibiotics.
3. Tachycardia: The patient continues to experience tachycardia without a clear etiology, which may be due to infection, sepsis, or other underlying causes.
4. Diabetes: The patient is at risk for hyperglycemia due to initiation of tube feeds and ongoing management of diabetes.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and previous cardiac arrest with anoxic brain injury and seizure. He is being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with tobramycin and ciprofloxacin. The patient has been experiencing multiple medical complications, including acute mental status secondary to anoxic brain injury/seizures, respiratory failure/VAP, tachycardia, eosinophilia, hypercalcemia, SMV thrombus, and metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Mental Status: The patient's prognosis regarding mental status is poor due to the anoxic brain injury and seizure activity. He is not interactive and requires continued antiepileptic therapy.
2. Respiratory Failure/VAP: The patient has been on tube continuous mechanical ventilation (TCM) for 24 hours and tolerating it well. He has a vigorous cough and is being treated with tobramycin and ciprofloxacin for VAP. However, his coughing worsened overnight, and he appeared uncomfortable, especially with worsened tachycardia. He was switched to pressure support ventilation (PSV) and improved.
3. Tachycardia: No clear etiology of tachycardia has been identified. The patient is not withdrawing and is on standing lorazepam. He did not respond to fentanyl

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis complicated by pseudocysts, previous episodes of cardiac arrest with anoxic brain injury and seizure, being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with tobramycin and ciprofloxacin.

The patient's current condition includes:
1. AMS (Altered Mental Status) secondary to anoxic brain injury/Seizures. The patient is not interactive, has suffered two PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity) arrests, and has poor prognosis regarding mental status.
2. Respiratory failure/VAP. The patient is tolerating tracheostomy tube change well and is on a two-week course of tobramycin and ciprofloxacin for VAP treatment.
3. Pancreatitis. The patient has severe necrotizing pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation. There are no plans for surgical intervention, and lipase levels are trending down.
4. Eosinophilia. The patient's eosinophil count continues to increase despite being off bactrim for several days. The concerning medications include tobramycin, linezolid, ciprofloxacin, and dilantin.
5. S/p PEA arrest. This was likely secondary to mucous plugging from VAP.
6. Diabetes. The patient had hypoglycemia during PEA arrest after initiation of glargine.

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of severe alcoholic pancreatitis, who has been hospitalized for respiratory failure, tracheostomy, PEA arrest, anoxic encephalopathy, seizures, and SMV thrombosis. He was readmitted from rehab for continued seizures, hypercalcemia, and SMV thrombosis. The patient was transferred to the MICU after another PEA arrest, possibly due to mucous plugging. He also has a history of Pseudomonas hospital-acquired pneumonia (HCAP) and Stenotrophomonas urinary tract infection.

The patient's current condition includes acute respiratory failure, improving but with continued coughing. He has been on tracheal collar recently. A bronchoscopy was performed, showing some irritation near the trachea and a minor amount of purulent secretions in the lingula. The patient is receiving lidocaine for coughing and will also try guaifenesin.

The patient is being treated for Pseudomonas HCAP with ciprofloxacin and tobramycin until August 3rd. He has altered mental status, which is multifactorial, including recent PEA arrest, hypercalcemia, resolving infections, and seizures. His pancreatitis and pseudocysts are being managed, and he is tolerating tube feeds. The patient has an SMV thrombus, for which he will receive a 6-month course of anticoagulation.

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status. The patient has a history of anoxic brain damage, acute respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, altered mental status, and seizure. The patient underwent bronchoscopy without significant secretions or inflammation, and continues to cough frequently but responds to lidocaine infusions. The patient has been febrile and started on robitussin. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 101.5°C, heart rate of 120s, blood pressure ranging from 96/34 mmHg to 145/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25-33 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on various medications including heparin sodium, famotidine, fentanyl, lorazepam, and dilantin. The patient's lab results show leukocytosis, elevated WBC count, increased Hct, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient has been diagnosed with leukocytosis, anoxic brain damage, acute pancreatitis, respiratory failure, sepsis, altered mental status, and seizure. The patient's current condition is stable in the ICU, receiving proper nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylactic treatments for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP. The patient's code status is full code, and the current disposition is unknown.

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Infection: The patient's fever and leukocytosis indicate a possible infection, which could worsen if not properly managed.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure and persistent tachycardia suggest a risk of further respiratory compromise.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis without organ dysfunction indicates a systemic inflammatory response, which can progress to septic shock if not treated promptly.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient's acute pancreatitis, specifically necrotizing pancreatitis, poses a risk of complications such as infected pancreatic necrosis or pancreatic pseudocyst.
5. Seizure: The patient's seizure history increases the risk of recurrent seizures, which can be potentially life-threatening if not managed appropriately.
6. Anoxic Brain Damage: The patient's pre-existing anoxic brain damage puts him at risk of neurological deterioration and potential long-term disability.
7. Blood Clots: The patient's immobilization in the ICU increases the risk of developing blood clots, particularly deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
8. Pressure Ulcers: Prolonged immobility in the ICU increases the risk of developing pressure ulcers, which can lead to infection and other complications.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory values, and clinical progress to promptly identify and manage any potential medical complications.

The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of prolonged hospitalization following pancreatitis, pseudocyst, SMV thrombosis, chronic respiratory failure, PEA arrest x 2, seizures, and hypercalcemia. The patient's current condition includes acute respiratory failure, coughing fits, anoxic brain injury/AMS, hypercalcemia, leukocytosis, eosinophilia, pancreatitis, SMV thrombus, and hyponatremia.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving but still tachypneic. Pulmonary toilet, CXR, and sputum culture will be rechecked. Steroids may be considered if bronchoscopy shows moderate inflammation.
2. Coughing fits: The coughing may be related to tracheostomy placement and could be CNS triggered. A longer tracheostomy tube might be needed, and lidocaine will be held for now.
3. Anoxic brain injury/AMS: The patient's neurological status has not shown obvious change over the past day. The multifactorial etiology behind AMS includes recent anoxia, continued seizure activity, hypercalcemia, and medications. Rapid improvement is not expected.
4. Hypercalcemia: Presumably due to immobilization, levels are normalizing. Calcium levels will be monitored.
5. Leukocytosis: Coverage for Pseudomonas VAP and stenotroph

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of prolonged hospitalization following pancreatitis, pseudocyst, SMV thrombosis, chronic respiratory failure, PEA arrest x 2, seizures, hypercalcemia. He has been experiencing acute respiratory failure, coughing fits, anoxic brain injury/AMS, hypercalcemia, leukocytosis, eosinophilia, pancreatitis, SMV thrombus, and hyponatremia.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.5 C (101.3 F), heart rate of 117 bpm, blood pressure of 145/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. He is on CPAP/PSV mode ventilation with a tidal volume of 590 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 15 cmH2O, respiratory system compliance of 89, and fractional inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's physical examination reveals general hiccups, clear lungs without wheeze or rhonchi, tachycardia, soft abdomen with bowel sounds present, no rashes, and warm extremities.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 15.6 thousand/mm3, hemoglobin level of 7.2 g/dL, platelet count of 437 K/uL, blood glucose levels ranging from 120 to 231 mg/dL, sodium level of 9 mg/dL, potassium level of 15 mEq/L, chloride level of 3.6 mEq/L, bicarbonate level of 17.3 mEq/L, magnesium level of 1.5 mg/dL, calcium level of 9.1 mg/dL, and phosphorus level of 2.3 mg/dL. The patient also has an elevated leukocyte count with neutrophils at 63.8%, lymphocytes at 21.0%, and eosinophils at 10.7%. Other lab results indicate elevated levels of CK, CKMB, Troponin-T, LDH, and abnormal liver function tests.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, potential medical complications that can arise include respiratory failure due to tracheostomy irritation and inflammation, continued seizures, hypercalcemia, leukocytosis, eosinophilia, pancreatitis, SMV thrombus, and hyponatremia.

Summary:
Summary:
- 28-year-old male with a history of prolonged hospitalization due to pancreatitis, pseudocyst, SMV thrombosis, chronic respiratory failure, PEA arrest x2, seizures, and hypercalcemia.
- Currently experiencing acute respiratory failure, resolving but still tachypneic, on tracheostomy collar.
- Coughing fits possibly related to tracheostomy placement, no purulent sputum production.
- Anoxic brain injury with altered mental status, no obvious neurological change over the past day.
- Hypercalcemia treated with pamidronate and calcitonin, levels normalizing.
- Leukocytosis being covered for Pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and stenotrophomonas urinary tract infection (UTI).
- Eosinophilia possibly related to prior bactrim exposure or dilantin.
- Pancreatitis with pseudocysts, no evidence of super-infection.
- SMV thrombus requires 6-month anticoagulation.
- Hyponatremia with plans to send urine lytes to evaluate for SIADH.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving but he remains tachypneic. Continued monitoring and management of respiratory support is necessary.
2. Coughing fits: Further investigation is needed to determine the cause of the coughing fits. Possible triggers include tracheostomy placement

1. Respiratory Failure/VAP (Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia): The patient has been diagnosed with respiratory failure and VAP caused by Stenotrophomonas. However, the patient's coughing worsened overnight, indicating a possible worsening of the respiratory condition. Further evaluation, such as CXR and sputum cultures, is recommended.

2. AMS (Altered Mental Status) secondary to Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures: The patient has suffered two PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity) arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity. The prognosis regarding mental status is poor. The patient is not interactive and requires continued EEG monitoring. Antiepileptic drugs like keppra, phenytoin, and ativan are being used for seizure prophylaxis.

3. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia likely secondary to SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone) from multiple neuro insults. The electrolyte panel shows a sodium level of 324 mEq/L. Further evaluation with ultras and trend of sodium levels is recommended.

4. Eosinophilia: The patient has an increasing eosinophil count despite being off

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis and pseudocysts. He has suffered two episodes of pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity. The patient is currently being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with tobramycin and ciprofloxacin. 

The patient's current medical conditions and potential complications include:

1. Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures: The patient has suffered two PEA arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity. Prognosis regarding mental status is poor.

2. Respiratory Failure/VAP: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure due to VAP caused by Stenotrophomonas. He is on tobramycin and ciprofloxacin therapy, which will be completed on August 3rd. Nebulizers are used as needed, and the patient may return to tracheostomy care management today if tolerated. A bronchoscopic evaluation was performed, and there is no anatomical cause for coughing.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a prolonged hospitalization history following pancreatitis, pseudocyst, SMV thrombosis, chronic respiratory failure, PEA arrest twice, seizures, and hypercalcemia. He is currently in the ICU with various medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute respiratory failure: The patient is on pressure support ventilation (PSV) and oxygenation is good. It is planned to wean him to a lower level of support today. There is an ongoing concern about treating his known pneumonia due to low antibiotic levels.

2. Coughing fits: These may be related to tracheostomy placement, as the sputum is thick and possibly not being adequately treated. There is also a possibility of CNS involvement, and a longer tracheostomy may be needed. Lidocaine has been held for now.

3. Anoxic brain injury/Acute Mental Status Changes (AMS): There have been no obvious neurological changes over the past day. The AMS could be due to recent anoxia, continued seizure activity, hypercalcemia, and medications. It is unlikely that there will be rapid improvement.

4. Hyponatremia: This is suggested by urine electrolytes indicating SIADH. Fluid restriction will be attempted through pharmacy adjustment of IV medications and nutrition adjustment to tube feeds.

5. Leukocytosis: Coverage is being provided for Pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia

- The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of prolonged hospitalization following pancreatitis, pseudocyst, SMV thrombosis, chronic respiratory failure, PEA arrest x 2, seizures, and hypercalcemia.
- The patient is on mechanical ventilation (CPAP/PSV) and is oxygenating well.
- He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is coughing frequently, which may be due to thick sputum and possible pneumonia.
- The patient is experiencing coughing fits that manifest as seizure activity, possibly related to tracheostomy placement or CNS triggered.
- He has anoxic brain injury and altered mental status (AMS) due to recent anoxia, continued seizure activity, hypercalcemia, and medications.
- The patient's sodium levels are low, suggesting SIADH, and he is being fluid restricted.
- He has leukocytosis, which is being covered for Pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and stenotrophomonas urinary tract infection (UTI).
- The patient's eosinophil count is elevated, and further investigation is needed to determine the cause.
- Abdominal imaging shows pseudocysts that have not changed appreciably, with no evidence of super-infection.
- The patient has an SMV thrombus and requires anticoagulation therapy.
- He also has metabolic acidosis.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a chief complaint of s/p PEA arrest. The patient is currently unresponsive and in encephalopathy. The patient has a history of leukocytosis, necrotizing pancreatitis, acute respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, altered mental status, and seizure. The patient is receiving nutrition through NovaSource Renal (Full) at 40 mL/hour and regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control. The patient has multiple lines including a PICC line. Prophylaxis measures include DVT prevention with Coumadin, stress ulcer prevention with PPI, and VAP prevention. The patient's code status is full code, and the patient's current disposition is in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's history of leukocytosis and sepsis suggests an ongoing infection, which can lead to sepsis and potentially organ dysfunction.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further deterioration in oxygenation and ventilation.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient's necrotizing pancreatitis can progress, leading to complications such as infected pancreatic necrosis or abscess formation.
4. Altered Mental Status: The patient's encephalopathy and altered mental status may persist or worsen, potentially resulting in prolonged ICU stay and increased risk of complications.
5. Seizure: The patient

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and previous PEA arrests. He has suffered an anoxic brain injury with seizure activity and is currently being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with tobramycin and ciprofloxacin. The patient's mental status is poor due to AMS secondary to anoxic brain injury/seizures. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure/VAP: The patient has a history of respiratory failure and is currently being treated for VAP caused by Stenotrophomonas. He will continue to receive tobramycin and ciprofloxacin until August 3rd. The plan is to switch from oral ciprofloxacin to IV ciprofloxacin due to poor PO bioavailability. Nebulizers will be used as needed, and the patient will be returned to tidal volume-controlled mandatory ventilation (TCM) today if tolerated. A bronch will be performed to identify any anatomical causes for coughing. Steroids may be considered.

2. Fever and Leukocytosis: The patient has fever and leukocytosis with no clear source at this time. Cultures are pending, and the most likely source of infection is pulmonary considering the cough. The patient will continue on the current antibiotic regimen, and the trend in fever curve and white blood cell count will be monitored.

3.

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis and pseudocysts. He has suffered two PEA arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity. He is currently being treated for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) with tobramycin and ciprofloxacin, despite having rising white blood cell count and fevers. The patient also has hyponatremia likely secondary to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), which is consistent with neurologic insults. He is volume overloaded, so a trial of diuresis will be given if no improvement is seen after fluid restriction.

The patient's respiratory status is concerning due to respiratory failure/VAP. He has a vigorous cough and tolerates pressure support (PS) better than mandatory ventilation (TCM). The sputum culture is growing 4+ Gram-negative rods despite double coverage with tobramycin and ciprofloxacin. It is unclear whether this represents a new pneumonia or inadequately treated VAP, or if there might be another infection present. An infectious disease (ID) consult has been requested for antibiotic management in a patient with multiple allergies and already being double covered for GNRs.

The patient has tachycardia with no clear etiology. He is not withdrawing and is on standing lorazepam. The tachycardia did not respond to fentanyl boluses or extra loraz
