   28 yo man with h/o recent admission with necrotizing pancreatitis c/b
   pseudocysts, s/p PEA arrest x2 with anoxic brain injury and seizures,
   with ongoing fevers likely secondary to resistant pseudomonas VAP.
   Fever/Leukocytosis:  Most likely secondary to pneumonia as sputum
   growing 2 colonies of pseudomonas.  Now on ceftaz and tobra.  WBC
   improving, and clinically improved.
   - continue tobra (d1 = [**7-23**]) , but reduce frequency to q 48 hours given
   that 36 hour trough was 1.6. Last day [**8-14**]
   - continue ceftaz  (day 1 = [**7-31**]) as double coverage. Last day [**8-14**]
   - cosider meropenem if febrile or unstable; skin blistering occurred in
   the setting of anasarca and occurred predominantly on the legs which is
   atypical for a drug rash; nevertheless, we will reserve [**Last Name (un) **] unless
   absolutely necessary
   - f/u colisitin sensitivies for pseudomonas, though would prefer to
   avoid this as it can cause irreversible renal failure
   - appreciate ID recs
   .
   AMS secondary to Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures.  Patient has suffered
   two PEA arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity.  Not
   interactive.  He was previously in has been loaded with phenytoin.  Has
   two witnessed tonic clonic seizures last night.  Prognosis regarding
   mental status is poor.
   - continue keppra 1 g [**Hospital1 **]
   - reloaded dilantin [**8-1**] with one gram, changed dosing to 100mg at 8 am
   and 4 pm, and 200 mg at midnight, level 3.5 this morning; will follow
   up with neuro
   - continue standing ativan
   -per neuron increased dilantin to 200mg [**Hospital1 **] 100mg daily
    .
   Respiratory failure/VAP.  Patient had vigorous cough and has been
   tolerating PS better than TCM.  On coverage for resistant pseudomonas
   vap.  Coughing fits seem to be do to irritation as he is s/p bronch
   without obvious source.  Tolerated trach mask for a few hours yesterday
   and returned to PS o/n
   - continue tobra/ ceftaz
   - continue nebs PRN
   - continue to try trach mask as tolerated
   .
   Hypothyroid-seen on yesterday
s TFTs. Endocrine recommended starting
   levoxyl 25mcg daily with repeat TFTs in 2 wks.
   .
   Anemia.  Likely multifactorial, chronic disease, phlebotomy.  Is slow
   drop, s/p 2 u PRBCs yesterday with appropriate bump (although had one
   hct that was likely spuriously low).
   - cont to monitor hct
   - stable, heparin resumed.
   - guaiac stools
   .
   Hyponatremia.  [**Month (only) 8**] be central SIADH due to anoxic brain injury and
   seizures.  Also may be hypovolemic.
   - continued to have concentrated TFs and abx
   - Na slightly improved with trial of lasix yesterday, can continue
   lasix today
   .
   Tachycardia.  No clear etiology of tachycardia.  Did not respond to
   fentanyl boluses or extra ativan doses.  Did not respond it IVF
   boluses, either.  Seemed to worsen with coughing fits.  Likely
   partially related to fever, and is improving as fever curve is starting
   to decrease.
   - telemetry
   .
   Pancreatitis:  Patient with severe necrotizing pancreatitis earlier in
   course of critical illness with pseudocyst formation.  No plans for
   surgical invention.  CT scan of the abdomen on [**7-25**] shows stable
   pancreatic pseudocysts.  Lipase continues to trend downward.
   - trending pancreatic enzymes
   - continue tube feeds
   Eosinophilia.  Now PMNs have returned to [**Location 201**], eosinophilia has come
   back; may have been secondary to bactrim exposure.
   .
   S/p PEA arrest.  This is felt to be secondary to mucous plugging from
   VAP, continue suctioning as needed.  Additionally, patient was
   hypoglycemic on the floor in setting of recently starting glargine.
   - monitor on tele
   Diabetes.  Had hypoglycemia during PEA arrest after initation of
   glargine.  In setting of worsening infection, has had increasing
   hyperglycemia
   - follow fingersticks and cover with HISS, which has been titrated up
   - if long acting insulin is needed will start low given recent
   hypoglycemia
   .
   Hypercalcemia: Unclear etiology, but most likely secondary to bone
   turnover from being immobile and poor kidney excretion.   S/p
   pamidronate and Calcitonin.  Ca stable recently.
   - appreciate Endo recs
   .
   SMV thrombus.  S/p heparin to coumadin bridging for SMV thrombus likely
   secondary to severe pancreatitis, has had subtherapeutic INR and
   started on heparin gtt yesterday but stopped in the setting of dropped
   hct.
   - would continue to bridge with heparin as long as hct stablized
   - continue coumadin with plan for 6 month course
   - increase coumadin from 1 to 2 mg because of INR 1.9 and flagyl being
   stopped
   .
   Metabolic acidosis.  Likely multifactorial secondary to prior saline
   infusion and seizures.
   - follow bicarb
   Access.  PICC has only one working port through this morning, when
   flushed again.  Continue with current PICC.

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis complicated by pseudocysts. He has experienced two episodes of pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and has sustained anoxic brain injury with seizures. He is currently on coverage for resistant pseudomonas ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's mental status is poor, and he is not interactive. He has been loaded with phenytoin and is on keppra, dilantin, and ativan for seizure prophylaxis. He is also on tobra and ceftaz to treat the VAP.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure/VAP: The patient has ongoing fevers and leukocytosis likely secondary to pneumonia, which may progress to severe sepsis or septic shock if not adequately controlled.
2. Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures: The patient's prognosis regarding mental status is poor due to the anoxic brain injury and seizure activity. There is a risk of further seizures and potential neurological deterioration.
3. AMS (Altered Mental Status): The patient's mental status is altered due to the anoxic brain injury and seizures. This can lead to difficulty in communication and decision-making.
4. Hypothyroidism: The patient has been started on levoxyl for hypothyroidism, which should be monitored with repeat thyroid function tests in two weeks.
5. Anemia: The patient has

He is currently in the ICU with ongoing fevers likely secondary to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is on mechanical ventilation and has tracheostomy tube in place. His vital signs are stable, but he has an elevated heart rate (tachycardia) without a clear etiology. He has been improving clinically with improved fever curve and WBC count.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. VAP: The patient has sputum growing 2 colonies of pseudomonas, indicating a bacterial infection in the lungs. He is already on ceftazidime and tobramycin, which should help treat the infection. It is important to continue monitoring his respiratory status and lab results.
2. AMS (Altered Mental Status) secondary to Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures: The patient's mental status is improving but the prognosis is poor. He is on keppra, dilantin, and ativan for seizure control. Regular monitoring of neurologic status is required.
3. Hyponatremia: The patient has low sodium levels, which may be due to central SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone) secondary to anoxic brain injury and seizures. Close monitoring of serum sodium and

   pseudocysts, s/p PEA arrest x2 with anoxic brain injury and seizures,
   with ongoing fevers likely secondary to VAP which is overall improving.
   VAP/Respiratory failure:  Sputum growing 2 colonies of pseudomonas in
   addition to ALCALIGENES XYLOSOXIDANS.  Now on ceftaz and tobra with
   fever curve and WBC improving..  WBC improving, and clinically
   improved.  Patient is not tolerated TCM trials due to coughing fits.

   comfort.
   - continue tobra (d1 = [**7-23**] q 48 hours until [**8-14**]
   - continue ceftaz  (day 1 = [**7-31**]) until [**8-14**]
   - cosider meropenem if febrile or unstable; skin blistering occurred in

   atypical for a drug rash; nevertheless, we will reserve [**Last Name (un) **] unless
   absolutely necessary

   avoid this as it can cause irreversible renal failure
   - appreciate ID recs

   .

   two PEA arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity.
   Overall mental status is improving, but prognosis regarding mental

He is receiving multiple medications and treatments for these conditions.

3. AMS: The patient's anoxic brain injury and seizures have resulted in ongoing mental status changes. There is a poor prognosis for full recovery of mental status.
4. Diabetes: The patient's recent hypoglycemia and increasing hyperglycemia indicate uncontrolled blood sugar levels. Poor glyc

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis, complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), anoxic brain injury from previous pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest due to mucous plugging, and subsequent tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. The patient experienced a seizure as a result of these complications. The patient's allergies include meropenem. 

24-hour events include downsizing the tracheostomy tube to a 6 and performing bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL). The patient's medications include heparin sodium, lorazepam (Ativan), famotidine (Pepcid), and others listed below. 

Review of systems is unchanged from admission except for coughing episodes. Flow sheet data shows the patient's vital signs, hemodynamic monitoring, fluid balance, respiratory support, and other relevant measurements. 

Physical examination reveals a well-nourished patient without acute distress. Neurological examination is notable for attentive behavior and purposeful movement but does not assess tone. 

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly decreased hematocrit and platelet count, normal creatinine, and abnormal liver function tests. Other lab values are within normal range. 

Assessment and plan include anemia, electrolyte and fluid disorder, leukocytosis, anoxic brain damage, acute pancreatitis with necrotizing features, respiratory failure

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of pancreatitis complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), anoxic brain injury from a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest due to mucous plugging, and seizure disorder. He has undergone tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placements. The patient is currently experiencing coughing episodes and has had a bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) performed. His allergies include meropenem, and he is currently on various medications including heparin sodium, lorazepam (Ativan), famotidine (Pepcid), and others. The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 38.1°C (100.5°F), heart rate 114 bpm, blood pressure 113/53 mmHg, respiratory rate 31 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 100%. The patient's laboratory results indicate anemia, leukocytosis, elevated lactic acid levels, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's current assessment includes anoxic brain damage, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), pancreatitis, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and altered mental status. The plan includes continuing cefaz and Tobramycin until August 14th, adjusting the ventilator settings, monitoring for seizure activity, and evaluating for potential complications such as SIADH, tachycardia, eosinophilia

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis and subsequent pseudocysts. He has experienced two PEA arrests, resulting in anoxic brain injury and seizures. The patient is currently in the ICU for ongoing fevers likely secondary to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The sputum culture grew two colonies of Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and the patient is being treated with tobramycin and ceftazidime.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Anoxic Brain Damage: The patient has suffered two PEA arrests and subsequent anoxic brain injury. This has led to altered mental status, which is expected to have a poor prognosis.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure, most likely due to VAP. He is currently on CPAP/PSV mode on the ventilator with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O.
3. Sepsis Without Organ Dysfunction: The patient has ongoing fevers, indicating possible sepsis. He is being treated with antibiotics, and his WBC count is improving.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient has severe necrotizing pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation. Surgical intervention is not planned, and the patient's pancreatic enzymes are trending downward.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, likely secondary to central

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis complicated by pseudocysts, post-cardiac arrest anoxic brain injury, and seizures. He has ongoing fevers likely secondary to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is overall improving. His VAP has been identified as being caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Alcaligenes xylosoxidans, and he is currently receiving treatment with Tobramycin and Ceftazidime.

The patient's tracheostomy tube size was decreased yesterday, and he has been experiencing coughing fits with attempts at tube feeding, so tube feeds have been withheld. His mental status is improving, but his prognosis regarding mental status is poor due to the anoxic brain injury and seizures he experienced.

He also has hypothyroidism, for which he has been prescribed levoxyl 25mcg daily. His anemia is likely multifactorial and chronic disease-related, and he is being monitored for hematocrit levels. He also has hyponatremia, which is believed to be central SIADH due to his anoxic brain injury and seizures.

The patient's tachycardia has no clear etiology and does not respond to fentanyl boluses, extra ativan doses, or IV fluid boluses. It appears to worsen with coughing fits and may be partially related to fever, which is improving. He continues to be

   VAP/Respiratory failure:  Sputum growing 2 colonies of pseudomonas in

   improved.  Patient is not tolerated TCM trials due to coughing fits.

3. Anoxic Brain Damage: The patient suffered from anoxic brain injury due to two episodes of PEA arrest. His mental status is improving but prognosis regarding mental status is poor.

   28 yo man with h/o recent admission with necrotizing pancreatitis c/b
   pseudocysts, s/p PEA arrest x2 with anoxic brain injury and seizures,
   with ongoing fevers likely secondary to VAP which is overall improving.
   VAP/Respiratory failure:  Sputum growing 2 colonies of pseudomonas in
   addition to ALCALIGENES XYLOSOXIDANS.  Now on ceftaz and tobra with
   fever curve and WBC improving..  WBC improving, and clinically
   improved.  Patient has not tolerated TCM trials due to coughing fits.
   Trach was downsized yesterday to a size 6 tube with hopes of improved
   patient comfort.
   - continue tobra (d1 = [**7-23**]) q 48 hours until [**8-14**]
   - continue ceftaz  (day 1 = [**7-31**]) until [**8-14**]
   - cosider meropenem if febrile or unstable; skin blistering occurred in
   the setting of anasarca and occurred predominantly on the legs which is
   atypical for a drug rash; nevertheless, we will reserve [**Last Name (un) **] unless
   absolutely necessary
   - f/u colisitin sensitivies for pseudomonas, though would prefer to
   avoid this as it can cause irreversible renal failure
   - appreciate ID recs
   -TCM trials as tolerated
   .
   AMS secondary to Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures.  Patient has suffered
   two PEA arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity.
   Overall mental status is improving, but prognosis regarding mental
   status is poor.
   - continue keppra 1 g [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue increase dose of dilantin 200-200-100 per neurology as
   dilantin level has been repeatedly subtherapeutic
   - continue standing ativan
   - appreciate neuro recs, now recommending 300mg IV Q6 with [**Hospital1 **] troughs
   and continuing PO for now. Will discuss with neuro re: defined course.
   .
   Hypothyroid.  TFTs consistent with hypothyroidism. Endocrine
   recommended starting levoxyl 25mcg daily with repeat TFTs in 2 wks.
   - continue levothyroxine
   .
   Anemia.  Likely multifactorial, chronic disease, phlebotomy.
   - cont to monitor hct
   - stable, heparin resumed.
   - guaiac stools
   .
   Hyponatremia.  [**Month (only) 8**] be central SIADH due to anoxic brain injury and
   seizures.   Stable.
   - continued to have concentrated TFs and abx
   .
   Tachycardia.  No clear etiology of tachycardia.  Did not respond to
   fentanyl boluses or extra ativan doses.  Did not respond it IVF
   boluses, either.  Seems to worsen with coughing fits.  Likely partially
   related to fever, and is improving as fever curve is starting to
   decrease.
   - telemetry
   .
   Pancreatitis:  Patient with severe necrotizing pancreatitis earlier in
   course of critical illness with pseudocyst formation.  No plans for
   surgical invention.  CT scan of the abdomen on [**7-25**] shows stable
   pancreatic pseudocysts.  Lipase continues to trend downward.
   - trending pancreatic enzymes
   - continue tube feeds
   Eosinophilia.  Now PMNs have returned to [**Location 201**], eosinophilia has come
   back; may have been secondary to bactrim exposure several weeks ago.
   .
   S/p PEA arrest.  This is felt to be secondary to mucous plugging from
   VAP, continue suctioning as needed.  Additionally, patient was
   hypoglycemic on the floor in setting of recently starting glargine.
   - monitor on tele
   Diabetes.  Had hypoglycemia during PEA arrest after initation of
   glargine.  In setting of worsening infection, has had increasing
   hyperglycemia
   - follow fingersticks and cover with HISS, which has been titrated up
   - if long acting insulin is needed will start low given recent
   hypoglycemia
   .
   Hypercalcemia: Unclear etiology, but most likely secondary to bone
   turnover from being immobile and poor kidney excretion.   S/p
   pamidronate and Calcitonin.  Ca stable recently.
   - appreciate Endo recs
   - trend calcium
   .
   SMV thrombus.  Undergoing heparin to coumadin bridging for SMV thrombus
   likely secondary to severe pancreatitis.  INR remains subtherapeutic
   - continue heparing to coumadin briding
   - continue coumadin with plan for 6 month course
   .
   Metabolic acidosis.  Likely multifactorial secondary to prior saline
   infusion and seizures.
   - follow bicarb

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis, pseudocysts, PEA arrest, anoxic brain injury, and seizures. He is currently in the ICU and has been diagnosed with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is improving. The patient also has hypothyroidism, anemia, hyponatremia, tachycardia, pancreatitis, eosinophilia, diabetes, hypercalcemia, SMV thrombus, and metabolic acidosis.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the conditions mentioned in the progress note include:

1. Infection: The patient is at risk for further infections due to his compromised immune system and prolonged use of medical devices such as the tracheostomy tube and central venous catheter.

2. Seizures: The patient's history of seizures increases the risk of recurrent seizure activity, especially if his neurologic status worsens or if there are any electrolyte imbalances.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is closely monitored due to his VAP and previous respiratory failure. There is a risk of worsening respiratory function if proper ventilation and infection control measures are not maintained.

4. Pancreatitis complications: The patient has severe necrotizing pancreatitis with pseudocysts. Complications such as pancreatic necrosis, abscess formation, or rupture of pseudocysts may occur, leading to further systemic infection

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis and pseudocysts.
- The patient has suffered two episodes of PEA arrest and has anoxic brain injury with ongoing seizure activity.
- The patient is currently experiencing fevers likely secondary to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
- The patient's white blood cell count is improving, indicating a positive response to antibiotics.
- The patient has been diagnosed with VAP and is currently being treated with ceftazidime and tobramycin. However, the patient has not tolerated tracheostomy changing trials due to coughing fits.
- The patient's tracheostomy tube was downsized to a size 6 tube to improve patient comfort.
- The patient has an anoxic brain injury and AMS (altered mental status) with a poor prognosis regarding mental status.
- The patient's seizures are being managed with keppra, dilantin, and ativan.
- The patient has hypothyroidism, and levoxyl has been started at a low dose with repeat TFTs in two weeks.
- The patient has anemia, likely multifactorial, chronic disease, and phlebotomy.
- The patient has hyponatremia, which is stable and believed to be central SIADH due to anoxic brain injury and seizures

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and previous PEA arrests with anoxic brain injury and seizures. He is currently in the ICU with ongoing fevers likely secondary to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is improving. The patient has not tolerated tracheostomy tube changes due to coughing fits and has been downsized to a size 6 tube. He is receiving ceftazidime and tobramycin for VAP, with plans to continue these antibiotics until August 14th. If febrile or unstable, meropenem may be considered, but skin blistering occurred with previous use. Colistin sensitivities for pseudomonas will be followed up, but its use may be avoided due to potential irreversible renal failure.

The patient also has AMS secondary to anoxic brain injury and seizures, with overall mental status improving but poor prognosis regarding mental status. He is on keppra 1 g, increasing doses of dilantin, and lorazepam for seizure management. Hypothyroidism is present, with thyroid function tests consistent with hypothyroidism. Levoxyl 25mcg daily has been started, with repeat TFTs in two weeks.

Anemia is likely multifactorial, chronic disease, and phlebotomy-related. Chronic disease and ongoing blood loss from NG tube are suspected contributors. Hyponatrem

The patient has been critically ill and has experienced multiple complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. VAP: The patient has developed ventilator-associated pneumonia, which is a common complication in critically ill patients who are on mechanical ventilation. The causative organism is resistant pseudomonas, making it challenging to treat.
2. Seizures: The patient is experiencing recurrent seizures, which may be attributed to the cerebral edema caused by the pancreatitis or due to other factors.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient initially presented with necrotizing pancreatitis, which has led to several complications.
4. SMV thrombosis: The patient has developed a superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombosis, which is a potential complication of pancreatitis.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient has ongoing fluid restrictions due to hyponatremia, a condition characterized by low levels of sodium in the blood.
6. Hypercalcemia: The patient has stable hypercalcemia, which requires monitoring.
7. PEG or doboff: The patient requires further evaluation regarding placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) or a feeding jejunostomy (doboff

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a complex medical history, including necrotizing pancreatitis, cerebral edema, multiple episodes of pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrests, recurrent seizures, and resistant pseudomonal ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 113 beats per minute, blood pressure of 124/65 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on aerosol-cool with tracheostomy tube ventilation. The patient's recent laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin levels, elevated creatinine levels, and abnormal liver function tests. The patient's imaging shows the presence of pseudomonas bacteria in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) cultures. 

Based on the information provided, potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, further seizures, progression of pancreatitis, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's current treatment plan includes antibiotic therapy for VAP, aggressive management of seizures, continued nutritional support through tube feeds, and systemic anticoagulation for DVT prophylaxis. The patient's disposition remains in the ICU with ongoing monitoring and management of his critical condition.

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis and subsequent pseudocysts. He has experienced two episodes of PEA arrest and has anoxic brain injury with ongoing seizure activity. The patient has also been diagnosed with hypothyroidism, anemia, hyponatremia, tachycardia, pancreatitis with pancreatic pseudocysts, eosinophilia, diabetes, hypercalcemia, SMV thrombus, and metabolic acidosis.

The patient's current condition includes ongoing fevers likely secondary to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He is currently receiving treatment with ceftazidime and tobramycin for the VAP, and his fever curve and WBC count are improving. The patient has not tolerated trials of tracheostomy due to coughing fits and has been placed on a size 6 tracheostomy tube for improved patient comfort.

The patient's mental status is improving, but the prognosis regarding mental status is poor. He is being treated with keppra, dilantin, and ativan for AMS secondary to anoxic brain injury and seizures. He has been started on levoxyl for hypothyroidism and will have repeat TFTs in 2 weeks. The patient's anemia is likely multifactorial, chronic disease, phlebotomy, and will continue to monitor HCT. He has stable hyponat

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and anoxic brain injury with seizures. He experienced two PEA arrests and is currently minimally responsive. The patient has various medical complications including VAP, AMS, hypothyroidism, anemia, hyponatremia, tachycardia, pancreatitis, eosinophilia, diabetes, hypercalcemia, SMV thrombus, metabolic acidosis, and FEN. The patient's condition is improving but with a poor prognosis regarding mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's sputum culture grew colonies of pseudomonas, indicating an infection that may lead to worsening respiratory failure.
2. Acute Mesial Syndrome (AMS): The patient's anoxic brain injury and seizures have resulted in AMS, which can progress to permanent neurological damage.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's thyroid function tests indicate hypothyroidism, requiring levothyroxine supplementation.
4. Anemia: The patient has chronic disease-related anemia, possibly exacerbated by phlebotomy.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia likely due to central SIADH secondary to anoxic brain injury and seizures.
6. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is not fully explained

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 28-year-old male who was admitted with necrotizing pancreatitis and developed pseudocysts. He experienced two episodes of pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity. The patient's mental status is improving, but the prognosis regarding mental status is poor.

The patient has been diagnosed with various conditions, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), hypothyroidism, anemia, hyponatremia, tachycardia, pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation, eosinophilia, diabetes, hypercalcemia, and a superior mesenteric vein (SMV) thrombus.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 30-year-old male with a history of etoh pancreatitis, multiple complications, anoxic brain injury, and pea arrests. He is currently in the ICU and has been unresponsive to commands. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and is receiving various medications including sedatives, antibiotics, and antiepileptic drugs.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period, which increases the risk of developing VAP. Proper mouth care and elevation of the head of bed should be continued as prophylaxis.
2. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI): The patient has a PICC line in place. There is a risk of developing a CLABSI, so careful line maintenance and monitoring for signs of infection are necessary.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient is immobile and at increased risk for thromboembolic events. Restarting systemic anticoagulation after the procedure is recommended to prevent DVT formation.
4. Hypotension and fluid imbalance: The patient's blood pressure is low, and there is a negative fluid balance indicated by the difference between input and output volumes. Close monitoring and appropriate fluid management are essential.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's ABG results show metabolic acidosis. Further investigation and correction of electrolyte imbalances are necessary

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 30-year-old male with a history of etoh pancreatitis, multiple complications, anoxic brain injury, and pea arrests. He is currently in the ICU for further management. 

The patient was unable to tolerate a procedure for obtaining a bedside peg tube and will require an open procedure later in the day. He is stable with no other significant events. 

The patient has allergies to meropenem and skin blisters. He received tobramycin and ceftazidime as antibiotics, with the latest culture showing resistance to ceftazidime. 

The patient is receiving multiple medications including lorazepam, famotidine, midazolam, fentanyl, and others. 

Review of systems is unchanged from admission except for cough and no shortness of breath. 

Flowsheet data shows vital signs within normal limits, including a temperature of 37.9°C, heart rate of 123 bpm, blood pressure of 118/54 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. 

The patient has a sinus tachycardia rhythm and is receiving respiratory support with a tracheostomy mask, controlled mechanical ventilation, and supplemental oxygen. 

Physical examination reveals an overweight/obese appearance, normal heart sounds, clear breath sounds, and no cyanosis or clubbing. 

Neurologic examination is not assessed due to the patient's unresponsive state

   28 yo man with h/o recent admission with necrotizing pancreatitis c/b
   pseudocysts, s/p PEA arrest x2 with anoxic brain injury and seizures,
   with ongoing fevers likely secondary to VAP which is overall improving.
   VAP/Respiratory failure:  Sputum growing 2 colonies of pseudomonas in
   addition to ALCALIGENES XYLOSOXIDANS.  Now on ceftaz and tobra with
   fever curve and WBC improving.  Has also been tolerating trach [**Last Name (un) 3041**].
   Trach was downsized [**8-6**] to a size 6 tube with hopes of improved patient
   comfort.  Trach secretions now show pseudomonas colonies with
   intermediate ceftaz resistance.
   - continue tobra (d1 = [**7-23**]) q 48 hours until [**8-14**]
   - continue ceftaz  (day 1 = [**7-31**]) until [**8-14**], but will discuss with ID
   re:  use of darbopenem
   - cosider meropenem if febrile or unstable; skin blistering occurred in
   the setting of anasarca and occurred predominantly on the legs which is
   atypical for a drug rash; nevertheless, we will reserve [**Last Name (un) **] unless
   absolutely necessary
   - f/u colisitin sensitivies for pseudomonas, though would prefer to
   avoid this as it can cause irreversible renal failure
   -TCM trials as tolerated
   .
   AMS secondary to Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures.  Patient has suffered
   two PEA arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity.
   Overall mental status is improving, but prognosis regarding mental
   status is poor.
   - continue keppra 1 g [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue increase dose of dilantin 200-200-100
   - continue standing ativan
   - appreciate neuro recs
   .
   Hypothyroid.  TFTs consistent with hypothyroidism. Endocrine
   recommended starting levoxyl 25mcg daily with repeat TFTs in 2 wks.
   - continue levothyroxine
   .
   Anemia.  Likely multifactorial, chronic disease, phlebotomy.
   - cont to monitor hct
   - stable, heparin resumed.
   .
   Hyponatremia.  [**Month (only) 8**] be central SIADH due to anoxic brain injury and
   seizures.   Worsened yesterday with lasix.  [**Last Name (un) 567**] stim was apporpirate
   so not likely to be due to adrenal insufficiency.
   - continued to have concentrated TFs and abx
   - will [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (un) **] stim test today
   .
   Tachycardia.  No clear etiology of tachycardia.  Did not respond to
   fentanyl boluses or extra ativan doses.  Did not respond it IVF
   boluses, either.  Seems to worsen with coughing fits.  Likely partially
   related to fever, and is improving as fever curve is starting to
   decrease.
   - telemetry

Summary:
The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis and pseudocysts, who experienced two episodes of pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest with subsequent anoxic brain injury and seizures. He is currently admitted to the ICU for severe respiratory failure due to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has multiple medical complications including hypothyroidism, anemia, hyponatremia, tachycardia, pancreatitis, eosinophilia, diabetes, hypercalcemia, SMV thrombus, and metabolic acidosis. He underwent an unsuccessful attempt at bedside percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) but had a successful PEG placement in the operating room. The patient's condition is improving, but his prognosis regarding mental status is poor. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been experiencing severe respiratory failure due to VAP. It is crucial to continue aggressive treatment with appropriate antibiotics and maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation support.
2. Pseudomonas infection: The patient's tracheostomy secretions show pseudomonas colonies with intermediate ceftaz resistance. This indicates a potential infection with this antibiotic-resistant organism, which requires careful monitoring and consideration of alternative antibiotic therapy.
3. Anoxic brain injury: The patient's two episodes of PEA arrest have resulted in anoxic brain injury, leading to AMS (altered mental status) and poor prognosis for

Summary:
The patient is a 71-year-old male with a chief complaint of being unable to tolerate oral intake. The patient was previously on invasive ventilation but it was successfully weaned off. However, the patient required reintubation due to respiratory distress and is currently on standby ventilation mode with a tracheostomy. The patient also has a newly placed PEG (percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy) tube for nutrition, as an attempt at bedside PEG was unsuccessful.

The patient has a history of allergies to meropenem and has been receiving multiple antibiotics including ceftazidime and tobramycin. He is on several ICU medications such as midazolam (versed), fentanyl, lorazepam (Ativan), and famotidine (Pepcid).

The patient's vital signs show tachycardia with a heart rate of 115 bpm and slightly elevated blood pressure. His respiratory rate is within normal limits, and his oxygen saturation is 100%. The patient's temperature is within normal range.

Fluid balance shows an intake of 851 mL and output of 1875 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 1024 mL. The patient's weight has decreased from 99.5 kg at admission to 92.1 kg currently.

Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and slightly decreased platelet count. Blood glucose levels are elevated, and kidney function appears to be normal based on creatinine levels. Liver

Summary:
Based on the provided information, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient. 

1. Infection: The patient has been diagnosed with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and is currently on antibiotics to treat the infection. However, the presence of intermediate ceftaz resistance suggests that the bacteria may not be fully susceptible to the current treatment. This could lead to a worsening infection and the need for alternative antibiotics.

2. Seizures: The patient has a history of seizures due to anoxic brain injury. It is important to continue seizure prophylaxis with medications such as keppra and dilantin to prevent further seizure activity.

3. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, which may be due to central SIADH caused by anoxic brain injury and seizures. Monitoring sodium levels and adjusting treatment accordingly is necessary.

4. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia does not have a clear etiology and has not responded to fentanyl boluses, ativan doses, or IV fluids. Continuous monitoring and further investigation are required to determine the cause.

5. Pancreatitis: The patient has severe necrotizing pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation. Although the lipase levels are trending downward, ongoing monitoring of pancreatic enzymes is needed. The patient is also at risk for developing complications related to the pseudocysts.

   Assessment and Plan
   28 yo man with h/o recent admission with necrotizing pancreatitis c/b
   pseudocysts, s/p PEA arrest x2 with anoxic brain injury and seizures,
   with ongoing fevers likely secondary to VAP which is overall improving.
   VAP/Respiratory failure:  Sputum growing 2 colonies of pseudomonas in
   addition to ALCALIGENES XYLOSOXIDANS.  Now on ceftaz and tobra with
   fever curve and WBC improving.  Has also been tolerating trach [**Last Name (un) 3041**].
   Trach was downsized [**8-6**] to a size 6 tube with hopes of improved patient
   comfort.  Trach secretions now show pseudomonas colonies with
   intermediate ceftaz resistance.
   - continue tobra (d1 = [**7-23**]) q 48 hours until [**8-14**]
   -dc ceftaz as now resistant..
   - cosider meropenem if febrile or unstable; skin blistering occurred in
   the setting of anasarca and occurred predominantly on the legs which is
   atypical for a drug rash; nevertheless, we will reserve [**Last Name (un) **] unless
   absolutely necessary
   - f/u colisitin sensitivies for pseudomonas, though would prefer to
   avoid this as it can cause irreversible renal failure
   -TCM trials as tolerated
   .
   AMS secondary to Anoxic Brain Injury/Seizures.  Patient has suffered
   two PEA arrests and has anoxic brain injury with seizure activity.
   Overall mental status is improving, but prognosis regarding mental
   status is poor.
   - continue keppra 1 g [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue increase dose of dilantin 200-200-200
   - continue standing ativan
   - appreciate neuro recs, IV boluses until at goal.
   .
   Hypothyroid.  TFTs consistent with hypothyroidism. Endocrine
   recommended starting levoxyl 25mcg daily with repeat TFTs in 2 wks.
   - continue levothyroxine
   .
   Anemia.  Likely multifactorial, chronic disease, phlebotomy.
   - cont to monitor hct
   - stable, heparin resumed.
   .
   Hyponatremia.  [**Month (only) 8**] be central SIADH due to anoxic brain injury and
   seizures.   [**Last Name (un) 567**] stim was apporpirate so not likely to be due to
   adrenal insufficiency.
   - continued to have concentrated TFs and abx
   -improved yesterday with NPO status.
   .
   Tachycardia.  No clear etiology of tachycardia.  Did not respond to
   fentanyl boluses or extra ativan doses.  Did not respond it IVF
   boluses, either.  Seems to worsen with coughing fits.  Likely partially
   related to fever, and is improving as fever curve is starting to
   decrease.
   - telemetry
   .
   Pancreatitis:  Patient with severe necrotizing pancreatitis earlier in
   course of critical illness with pseudocyst formation.  No plans for
   surgical invention.  CT scan of the abdomen on [**7-25**] shows stable
   pancreatic pseudocysts.  Lipase continues to trend downward.
   - trending pancreatic enzymes
   - continue tube feeds
   Eosinophilia.  Likely secondary to bactrim, cont to monitor.
   .
   S/p PEA arrest.  This is felt to be secondary to mucous plugging from
   VAP, continue suctioning as needed.  Additionally, patient was
   hypoglycemic on the floor in setting of recently starting glargine.
   - monitor on tele
   Diabetes.  Had hypoglycemia during PEA arrest after initation of
   glargine.  In setting of worsening infection, has had increasing
   hyperglycemia
   - follow fingersticks and cover with RISS, which has been titrated up
   - if long acting insulin is needed will start low given recent
   hypoglycemia
   .
   Hypercalcemia: Unclear etiology, but most likely secondary to bone
   turnover from being immobile and poor kidney excretion.   S/p
   pamidronate and Calcitonin.  Ca stable recently.
   - appreciate Endo recs
   - trend calcium
   .
   SMV thrombus.  Undergoing heparin to coumadin bridging for SMV thrombus
   likely secondary to severe pancreatitis.  INR remains subtherapeutic
   - lovenox to coumadin briding after G-tube placement
   .
   Metabolic acidosis.  Unclear etiology, but stable.  Possibly related to
   respiratory status.
   - follow bicarb
   - check VBG
   .
   FEN
 s/p PEG placement.

   ICU Care
   Nutrition: will likely resume TF
s today pending [**Doctor First Name 91**] recs.

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 28-year-old man with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis, pseudocysts, PEA arrest, anoxic brain injury, and seizures. The patient has been experiencing fevers likely secondary to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which is overall improving. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation and has a tracheostomy tube in place.

The patient's current medications include meropenem, tobramycin, famotidine, fentanyl, lorazepam, fosphenytoin, and levoxyl. The patient's recent lab results show an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin levels, elevated creatinine levels, and abnormal thyroid function tests.

The patient's medical conditions include VAP, AMS (acute mental status change) due to anoxic brain injury and seizures, hypothyroidism, anemia, hyponatremia, tachycardia, pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation, eosinophilia, history of PEA arrest, diabetes mellitus, hypercalcemia, and a thrombus in the superior mesenteric vein (SMV).

The potential medical complications that can arise in this case include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been experiencing fevers likely secondary to VAP. It is important to monitor for worsening respiratory symptoms, increased fever, and changes in sputum culture.

The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of recent admission for necrotizing pancreatitis, pseudocysts, PEA arrest, anoxic brain injury, and seizures. He is currently in the ICU with ongoing fevers likely secondary to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). His vital signs show a sinus tachycardia, normal blood pressure, and oxygen saturation of 100% on tracheal mask ventilation. The patient has a tracheostomy in place, which was downsized to size 6.

The patient's laboratory results indicate an elevated white blood cell count with a left shift, increased lactate level, and low platelet count. His renal function is impaired, as evidenced by an elevated creatinine level. Other lab abnormalities include hypothyroidism, hyponatremia, eosinophilia, hypercalcemia, anemia, and metabolic acidosis.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 28-year-old male with a history of etoh pancreatitis, multiple pea arrests, anoxic brain injury, and severe seizure disorder. He is currently improving slowly and is ready for rehabilitation today.

24-hour events include starting tube feeds, tolerating, and decreasing FiO2. The patient has allergies to meropenem and skin blisters. He has received various antibiotics, medications, and infusions as noted in the timeline.

Vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 110 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 115/58 mmHg to 127/80 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and SpO2 at 100%. The patient has sinus tachycardia on ECG.

Physical examination reveals no acute distress, with the patient being overweight/obese. The tracheostomy site is clear. Cardiovascular examination shows normal heart sounds, and peripheral pulses are present. Extremities show 1+ edema bilaterally. Musculoskeletal examination notes muscle wasting and inability to stand. Neurologic examination is incomplete due to the patient's condition.

Lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count, normal hemoglobin and platelet count, slightly decreased creatinine levels, and normal electrolyte levels. Other lab values are within normal range or not significantly abnormal.

The patient's plan includes continuing current medications, anticoagulation
